Award.AwardTitle: Student Support to Attend 7th Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics (ACM BCB 2016)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Annual ACM International Conference on Bioinformatics and Computational Biology (ACM BCB) is the premier conference in the areas of bioinformatics, computational biology, and biomedical informatics. The 7th ACM BCB 2016 will be held in Seattle WA, Oct.2-5, 2016, (http://acm-bcb.org/). The award will provide support for female keynote speaker and 25 selected students with high priority given to female and minority students and young professionals to participate in the conference. ACM-BCB conference provides a common platform to bridge important interdisciplinary research areas in computer science, mathematics, statistics, biology, bioinformatics, and biomedicine and an interactive forum which brings together experienced researchers, practitioners, and students from around the world to promote scientific understanding and findings in bioscience. Students will learn about advanced knowledge in bioinformatics and computational biology, enhance their knowledge in the cutting edge inter/multidisciplinary fields, and participate in special student activities aimed. To promote broad participation in this event, ACM BCB includes the "women in bioinformatics" initiative that aims to recruit and engage young female students and researchers in this interdisciplinary area. ACM BCB 2016 is inviting a distinguished female keynote speaker whose experience and success may inspire many students, especially underrepresented minorities and women, to enter this exciting field.

The ACM-BCB conference is a leading venue for presenting results and building a bioinformatics and computational biology community. The presented papers will appear will be included in the ACM BCB 2016 proceedings published by ACM Digital Library. To enhance the results dissemination, the authors of selected papers will be invited to adapt their papers for publication in a special issue of IEEE/ACM Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics (TCBB), or a special issue of IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics (J-BHI).

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the annual conference of ACM SIGBio, the ACM International Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics (ACMBCB) aims (1) to provide an interactive forum for researchers, practitioners, and students from around the world to promote scientific understanding and findings in bioscience, and (2) to strengthen interdisciplinary research across computer science, mathematics, statistics, biology, bioinformatics, and biomedicine. The objective of this NSF grant is to seek travel support for a female keynote speaker, and up to 25 selected young professionals including at least 20-30% female and minority to attend ACMBCB2016 in Seattle, WA during Oct. 2-5, 2016.  This NSF grant significantly broadens the participation of young professionals, maximizes their learning of advanced knowledge in bioinformatics, computational biology, and health informatics through the well-planned and organized conference activities, and advances their future research. This NSF grant makes large contribution to the training of next generation of researchers and educators in interdisciplinary informatics research that bridges computer science, biological science, biomedical science and other related areas.

 

The first key outcome is all applicants wrote a research abstract describing their key research Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, or Health Informatics beyond the research paper(s) or poster(s) submitted to ACMBCB2016. Upon faculty committee’s evaluation and selection, the awardees are provided another oral opportunity to present in The Young Professional Research Forum. Among 47 undergrad, master and PhD graduate students, post-docs, and newly graduated research scientists (all defined as young professionals) who submitted research abstracts, 23 made oral presentations with PPTs, and one PhD student helped organize and co-chair the research forum.  This forum was well attended with close to 50 attendees. It enables these bright young professionals to exchange their research ideas, and to gain visibility from the ACM bioinformatics and health informatics community.

 

The second key outcome is as a requirement for receiving this NSF travel award, these awardees attended the entire conference (oral and poster sessions) to interact with top bioinformatics and health informatics researchers attending ACMBCB2016. They also organized student social activities for peer interaction and networking.

 

The third outcome on is on diversity. One of the keynote speakers (Prof. Wendy W Chapman from University of Utah) and one of research forum co-chairs (Prof. May Dongmei Wang) are woman faculty. Among 23 awardees, there were 11 women, and one self-identified (voluntarily) under-representative minority with disability. The women participation average (11 out of 23) is significantly higher than the average percentage of women in computing, and this is a unique highlight of ACMBCB2016.
